elements.content: On the basis of an asymmetric, conjugated, partially or wholly deprotonated 5-(pyridin-3-yl)-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid (H2ppc), five new complexes [Co2(ppc)2­(H2O)] n (1), {[Co2(Hppc)4]­·[Co­(4,4′-bipy)2­(H2O)4]­·(OH)2­·10H2O} n (2), [Co2(Hppc)4­(4,4′-bipy)] n (3), {[Co­(ppc)­(pbbbm)]­·H2O} n (4) [pbbbm = 1,4-bis­(benzimidazole-1-ylmethyl)­benzene)], and [Co­(Hppc)2­(mbbbm)]2 (5) [mbbbm = 1,3-bis­(benzimidazole-1-ylmethyl)­benzene)] have been synthesized and characterized magnetically and structurally. Polymer 1, which has the Schläfli symbol (42·62·82)2­(42·6·83)2, is a three-dimensional (3D) network. Polymer 2 includes a mononuclear subunit and an infinite two-dimensional (2D) framework subunit, while polymer 3 is a 2D sheet structure. Polymer 4 is characterized by a one-dimensional double ladder-like chain structure. Complex 5 possesses a binuclear structure. Magnetization data for 1 with the Co2 units show the antiferromagnetic coupling in the Co2 units. No long-range magnetic ordering is observed for 1. 2, 3, and 5 display weak antiferromagnetic exchange interactions. For 4 with the similar Co2 units, it also exhibits antiferromagnetic coupling in the Co2 units, and the M(H) curve is consistent with the antiferromagnetic nature in the Co2 units. Variable temperature magnetic studies reveal that 2, 3, and 5 display weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The observed magnetization values, which were ∼2.5 Nβ at high field for 2, 3, and 5, are in accordance with the value anticipated for single uncompensated S = 1/2 spin.

elements.content: Five Co­(II)-complexes based on the H2ppc ligand were synthesized and characterized magnetically and structurally. Magnetization data for 1 and 4 with the Co2 units show the antiferromagnetic coupling in the Co2 units. No long-range magnetic ordering is observed for 1, 2, 3, and 5 displaying weak antiferromagnetic exchange interactions. Their M(H) data were also studied.

elements.content: In recent years, studies concerning crystal engineering as well as magnetism of molecule-based complexes with structures of low or high dimension have inspired a deep interest in different research groups. The research purpose was to obtain further knowledge about the essential magnetostructural correlations within the structure and how the spins in molecules and molecular assemblies are controlled to conceive functional applicable molecule-based materials. A crucial consideration for designing such materials is selecting short bridging ligands. Such ligands will definitely perform an important role when constructing molecular magnets since they are able to serve as efficient superexchange pathways to communicate a variety of magnetic information among the spin carriers. Until now, some kinds of short bridging ligands which can convey strong magnetic coupling have been studied, e.g., carboxylates, pseudohalides, oxalate, and so on. In addition, searching for new bridging ligands has long been of interest. In this presentation, an asymmetric, conjugated H2ppc () is chosen to be a potential candidate based on the considerations as follows: (i) one H2ppc ligand containing multidentate carboxylate, pyrazole, and pyridine is a potential multipurpose bridge that could facilitate strong magnetic coupling. As mentioned previously, in the synthesis of molecular magnetic materials, the carboxylate group with a variety of bridging modes thus resulting in different magnetic exchange pathways has been broadly applied. Additionally, the H2ppc ligand has one possible steric configuration by rotating pyridine rings with different angles, which therefore can exhibit versatile fashions to satisfy the space geometries of the metal ions; (ii) the entire molecule of the H2ppc ligand is a large conjugated system, and it possesses the favorable possibility of acting as an efficient superexchange pathway to convey a variety of magnetic information; (iii) the H2ppc spacer has a number of hydrogen donor sites, interaction sites, and coordination sites on the pyridine, pyrazole ring, or carboxylate, and the intermolecular π···π stacking sites on aromatic moieties. These are all advantageous in the construction of complexes; (iv) H2ppc and similar ligands have been proven to be good bridging linkers to isolate complexes, while the H2ppc ligand has seldom been explored in coordination chemistry. The combination of the H2ppc ligand and different metal ions can be permitted in the formation of complexes possessing pleasing architectures, novel topologies, and excellent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, studies concerning crystal engineering as well as magnetism of molecule-based complexes with structures of low or high dimension have inspired a deep interest in different research groups. The research purpose was to obtain further knowledge about the essential magnetostructural correlations within the structure and how the spins in molecules and molecular assemblies are controlled to conceive functional applicable molecule-based materials. A crucial consideration for designing such materials is selecting short bridging ligands. Such ligands will definitely perform an important role when constructing molecular magnets since they are able to serve as efficient superexchange pathways to communicate a variety of magnetic information among the spin carriers. Until now, some kinds of short bridging ligands which can convey strong magnetic coupling have been studied, e.g., carboxylates, pseudohalides, oxalate, and so on. In addition, searching for new bridging ligands has long been of interest. In this presentation, an asymmetric, conjugated H2ppc () is chosen to be a potential candidate based on the considerations as follows: (i) one H2ppc ligand containing multidentate carboxylate, pyrazole, and pyridine is a potential multipurpose bridge that could facilitate strong magnetic coupling. As mentioned previously, in the synthesis of molecular magnetic materials, the carboxylate group with a variety of bridging modes thus resulting in different magnetic exchange pathways has been broadly applied. Additionally, the H2ppc ligand has one possible steric configuration by rotating pyridine rings with different angles, which therefore can exhibit versatile fashions to satisfy the space geometries of the metal ions; (ii) the entire molecule of the H2ppc ligand is a large conjugated system, and it possesses the favorable possibility of acting as an efficient superexchange pathway to convey a variety of magnetic information; (iii) the H2ppc spacer has a number of hydrogen donor sites, interaction sites, and coordination sites on the pyridine, pyrazole ring, or carboxylate, and the intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π stacking sites on aromatic moieties. These are all advantageous in the construction of complexes; (iv) H2ppc and similar ligands have been proven to be good bridging linkers to isolate complexes, while the H2ppc ligand has seldom been explored in coordination chemistry. The combination of the H2ppc ligand and different metal ions can be permitted in the formation of complexes possessing pleasing architectures, novel topologies, and excellent properties.

elements.content: In addition, the first row transition metal (Co, Ni, and Cu) coordination compounds have currently been a focus of research due to their variant oxidation states, which permit two vital parameters to be changed, namely, the magnetic anisotropy and spin quantum number. Among them, because the systems exhibit substantial orbital contributions to the magnetic moments and therefore possess strong magnetic anisotropy, the exchange coupled magnetic cobalt­(II) complexes are fascinating to study. Even though some molecule-based magnetic cobalt­(II) complexes have been reported, it is hard to design and synthesize molecular cobalt­(II) complexes that have predictable magnetic properties due to the fact that the structural factors controlling the exchange coupling are elusive and complicated. As a consequence, the exact nature of the magnetic superexchange, magneto-structural correlations and the methods by which these factors contribute to the anisotropy of cobalt­(II) centers are unquestionable vital issues requiring further investigation. The research concerning magnetic cobalt­(II) complexes may be in favor of comprehending the fundamental magnetic phenomena, and will also help create a valid platform for further exploitation of newfangled functional magnetic materials. Herein, reactions of cobalt­(II) salt with the H2ppc ligand, along with some N-donor ligands, were further performed to explore the impact of organic ligands on the complex structures and relevant magnetic characteristics. In this article, the synthesis, magnetic properties, and crystal structures of five multidimensional Co­(II)-complexes (From 0D to 3D) were discussed in detail.

The research concerning magnetic cobalt(II) complexes may be in favor of comprehending the fundamental magnetic phenomena, and will also help create a valid platform for further exploitation of newfangled functional magnetic materials. In this article, the synthesis, magnetic properties, and crystal structures of five multidimensional Co(II)-complexes (From 0D to 3D) were discussed in detail.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information and Materials

H2ppc and other reagents with reagent grade quality are directly utilized without purification. C, H, and N elements were analyzed through a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were obtained from a PANalytical X'prtPro diffractometer, by using Cu Kα1 radiation. The magnetic experiment was placed in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Polymer 1 was fabricated through a hydrothermal reaction. H2ppc (0.0057 g, 0.03 mmol), Co­(OAc)2·4H2O (0.0075 g, 0.03 mmol), and NaOH (0.25 mL, 0.65 M) were put into 8 mL of distilled water and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL). The container was heated to 150 °C and maintained for 72 h, and then cooled to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C/h. Block purple crystals of 1 were gathered. Yield: 67% based on cobalt (the same below). Elemental anal. Calcd for C18H12Co2N6O5 (508.18): C, 42.37; H, 2.37; N, 16.47. Found: C, 42.35; H, 2.38; N, 16.48. elements.content: The diffraction data of 1–5 were measured on SATURN-724 or Rigaku RAXIS-IV diffractometer through graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Through direct methods and expanding with Fourier techniques, we solved the crystal structures of 1–5. All atoms except hydrogen were refined anisotropically. Full-matrix least-squares refinements for the final cycle were decided by the variable parameters and observed reflections. The mentioned calculations were carried out through SHELXL-2014 software. The processing parameters and crystallographic data for 1–5 were presented in . and show the χm T data at 300 and 2 K and Curie and Weiss constants of 1–5, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Experiment

The diffraction data of 1-5 were measured on SATURN-724 or Rigaku RAXIS-IV diffractometer through graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Through direct methods and expanding with Fourier techniques, we solved the crystal structures of 1-5. All atoms except hydrogen were refined anisotropically. Full-matrix least-squares refinements for the final cycle were decided by the variable parameters and observed reflections. The mentioned calculations were carried out through SHELXL-2014 software. The processing parameters and crystallographic data for 1-5 were presented in .  and  show the χm T data at 300 and 2 K and Curie and Weiss constants of 1-5, respectively.

1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P2­(1)/c and exhibits a (4,4)-connected 3D non-interpenetrating structure. In the asymmetrical unit, Co1 and Co2 ions are shown in a: Co1 is hexa-coordianted and Co2 is penta-coordinated. For hexacoordianted Co1 ion, it is in a distorted octahedral environment with O3, O6, and O5A from three ppc2– ligands, N3, N5, and N6D from three ppc2– ligands, in which O6 and N3 (O3 and N5) come from a ppc2– ligand (a). The penta-coordinated Co2 is connected by N2, N4, and N1C from three ppc2– ligands and O4B and O9 (O4B is from a ppc2– unit and O9 is from a coordinated water molecule). The coordination surrounding of Co2 can be described as a distorted trigonal bipyramidal (TBP). It can be embodied in the index of trigonality (τCo2 = 0.70). It should be pointed out that each nitrogen or oxygen atom of ppc2– ligand in 1 is involved in the coordination and the carboxylate groups in each ppc2– ligand adopt μ2-η1 coordination modes, which result in to a (4,4)-connected 3D structure. The bond angles surrounding Co1 and Co2 ions vary from 76.46(11) to 172.37(10)°. The distances of Co–O bonds range from 1.986 to 2.243 Å, while the Co–N bond lengths vary from 2.025 to 2.160 Å, which are in the normal range. The ppc2– ligand exhibits a μ4 bridging mode with all oxygen and nitrogen atoms taking part in coordination. This forms three typological bridges among metal ions: (i) the 2-fold N–N bridge from two ppc2– ligands, which creates an approximate centrosymmetric quasi-planar Co­(N–N)2Co hexagon with Co1···Co2 = 3.815 Å. In fact, the crystallographically independent Co1 and Co2 atoms are asymmetric; (ii) the monochelating O2C2N1 bridge, with Co1···Co1A = 5.930 and Co2···Co1B = 5.528 Å; and (iii) the pyridin bridge with Co1···Co1A = 7.854 and Co2···Co2B = 6.011 Å. Because of the coordination mode of the ppc2– ligand, the 2D undulated double layer which is parallel to the bc plane is formed (b). Such 2D undulated double layers were further connected to the 3D framework by ppc2– ligands. Furthermore, the π···π stacking interactions exist in 1 (interplanar separations: 3.549 Å; centroid–centroid separations: 3.573 Å) between intermolecular pyridine rings of ppc2– ligands. Additionally, the intramolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds [H···O distances (bond angles): 2.258 Å (126.87°) for O9–H9WA···O3; 1.927 Å (170.30°) for O9–H9W···O5] are detected in polymer 1, which further stabilize the 3D framework. For achieving further insight into the structure of 1, we can simplify ppc2– ligands and Co­(II) ions from the topological point of view. As discussed previously, each Co1 and Co2 can be abstracted as a four-connected node that links to four ppc2– ligands. Each crystallographically independent ppc2– can also be abstracted as a 4-connected node that connects four Co­(II) ions. In topological analysis, the coordinated water molecules were not considered. According to this simplification and indicated by TOPOS software, the structure of 1 can be seen as a (4,4)-connected 3D with the Schläfli symbol (42·62·82)2­(42·6·83)2 (b).

Crystal Structure of [Co2(ppc)2(H2O)] n  (1)

 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c and exhibits a (4,4)-connected 3D non-interpenetrating structure. In the asymmetrical unit, Co1 and Co2 ions are shown in a: Co1 is hexa-coordianted and Co2 is penta-coordinated. For hexacoordianted Co1 ion, it is in a distorted octahedral environment with O3, O6, and O5A from three ppc2- ligands, N3, N5, and N6D from three ppc2- ligands, in which O6 and N3 (O3 and N5) come from a ppc2- ligand (a). The penta-coordinated Co2 is connected by N2, N4, and N1C from three ppc2- ligands and O4B and O9 (O4B is from a ppc2- unit and O9 is from a coordinated water molecule). The coordination surrounding of Co2 can be described as a distorted trigonal bipyramidal (TBP). It can be embodied in the index of trigonality (τCo2 = 0.70). It should be pointed out that each nitrogen or oxygen atom of ppc2- ligand in 1 is involved in the coordination and the carboxylate groups in each ppc2- ligand adopt μ2-η1 coordination modes, which result in to a (4,4)-connected 3D structure. The bond angles surrounding Co1 and Co2 ions vary from 76.46(11) to 172.37(10)°. The distances of Co-O bonds range from 1.986 to 2.243 Å, while the Co-N bond lengths vary from 2.025 to 2.160 Å, which are in the normal range. The ppc2- ligand exhibits a μ4 bridging mode with all oxygen and nitrogen atoms taking part in coordination. This forms three typological bridges among metal ions: (i) the 2-fold N-N bridge from two ppc2- ligands, which creates an approximate centrosymmetric quasi-planar Co(N-N)2Co hexagon with Co1⋅⋅⋅Co2 = 3.815 Å. In fact, the crystallographically independent Co1 and Co2 atoms are asymmetric; (ii) the monochelating O2C2N1 bridge, with Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1A = 5.930 and Co2⋅⋅⋅Co1B = 5.528 Å; and (iii) the pyridin bridge with Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1A = 7.854 and Co2⋅⋅⋅Co2B = 6.011 Å. Because of the coordination mode of the ppc2- ligand, the 2D undulated double layer which is parallel to the bc plane is formed (b). Such 2D undulated double layers were further connected to the 3D framework by ppc2- ligands. Furthermore, the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions exist in 1 (interplanar separations: 3.549 Å; centroid-centroid separations: 3.573 Å) between intermolecular pyridine rings of ppc2- ligands. Additionally, the intramolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [H⋅⋅⋅O distances (bond angles): 2.258 Å (126.87°) for O9-H9WA⋅⋅⋅O3; 1.927 Å (170.30°) for O9-H9W⋅⋅⋅O5] are detected in polymer 1, which further stabilize the 3D framework. elements.content: 2 crystallizes in an orthorhombic system with space group Pnnm. Its asymmetric unit includes two crystallographically independent Co ions that adopt similar coordination surrounding (a). Polymer 2 includes two individual parts: One of the individual subunits exhibits a mononuclear structure, the other displays an infinite 2D framework subunit (b). Each six-coordinated Co2 center in a regular octahedral environment is formed by O5, O5D, O6, O6D atoms from four water molecules [Co(2)–O(5) = 2.079(8), Co(2)–O(6) = 2.087(8), O5D–Co2–O5 180°, O6D–Co(2)–O6 180°] and N7, N7E atoms [Co2–N7 = 2.183(11) Å, N7E–Co2–N7 180°] from two Hppc– units, which is a individual mononuclear subunit (c), while each Co1 is six-coordinated and is also in a distorted octahedral geometry. It is coordinated by O1, O1A atoms and N3, N3A, N3B, N6C atoms from four Hppc– ligands. Each carboxylate group in Hppc– ligands links Co1, adopting a μ1-η1:η0 coordination mode. Each Hppc– ligand links two Co1 ions, resulting in an individual 2D framework subunit (d). The Co1···Co1 distances are all 9.682 Å. The bond lengths of Co–O vary from 2.079(8) to 2.107(6) Å. The bond lengths of Co–N are in the range of 2.097(7)–2.183(11) Å. In both cases, they are in the normal range. The bond angles surrounding Co­(II) ions vary from 89.1(3) to 180°. The 2D layers with 1D channels, and the adjacent individual mononuclear subunits, which are located in the 1D channels (a), are further fabricated into a 3D supramolecular structure (b along the b axis and a along the c axis) through strong hydrogen bonds [O6W···O2, 2.726(4) Å; O6W–H6···O2 bond angle, 165.18°] between the coordinated H2O molecules of the individual mononuclear subunits and the carboxylate O atoms of Hppc– ligands. Additionally, there are π···π stacking interactions (interplanar separations: 3.496 Å; centroid–centroid separations: 3.828 Å) between the intermolecular pyridine rings of Hppc– ligands in the 2D layers and of 4,4′-bipy in the mononuclear subunits. Noticeably, the four lattice H2O molecules are linked to form an interesting hydrogen-bonding water cluster that consists of 10 water molecules (b,c), which run through the 1D channels (a). Additionally, the intermolecular N4–H4···O9W, O4W–H4W···O5W, O5W–H5W···O3W, O7W–H7WA···O2 and O3W–H3W···O1 hydrogen bonds among the foregoing water cluster, the coordinated water molecules of the individual mononuclear subunits and nitrogen (or oxygen) atoms of Hppc– ligands are observed with the N4···O9W distance of 2.730 Å [O4W···O5W, 2.710(4) Å; O5W···O3W, 2.730(5) Å; O7W···O2, 2.750(4) Å; O3W···O1, 2.776(4)] and the N4–H4···O9W bond angle of 164.10° [O4W–H4W···O5W, 170.96(4)°; O5W–H5W···O3W, 139.22(4)°; O7W–H7WA···O2, 171.60(4)°; O3W–H3W···O1, 134.25(4)°] that further stabilize the 3D supramolecular network (c). It should also be noted that the water clusters possibly perform crucial parts in the reinforcement or formation of a high-dimensional supramolecular structure. After all free water molecules were eliminated, polymer 2 is microporous, and its potential total solvent accessible volume calculated using PLATON is 25.8%.

elements.content: It should be pointed out that, during the course of the collecting crystals of polymer 2, polymer 3 is obtained due to the miscalculation of the Hppc– ligand (the equimolar hydrochloric acid is missing). Different from polymer 2, polymer 3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/c and exhibits a 3-connected 2D floor-like network. The independent unit of 3 includes one Co­(II) ion, two Hppc– anions, and half of a 4,4′-bipy molecule (a). Co1 center is six-coordinated and has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. This geometry includes O1, O3, N3, N6 atoms from two individual Hppc– anions that form the equatorial plane. N4 and N5A atoms from the 4,4′-bipy and Hppc– anion group occupy the apical positions. The bond lengths of Co–O range from 2.052(3) to 2.143(3) Å, which are within the range reported for octahedral environments. The Co–N bond lengths are 2.109(4), 2.127(4), 2.140(4), and 2.186(4) Å, respectively. The bond angles surrounding Co­(II) ions vary from 77.5(1) to 175.7(1)°. Each Hppc– anion connects two Co atoms (or as terminal ligand connects one Co atom) using its one carboxylate group and/or one pyridine group (b), additionally, the 4,4′-bipy ligands link adjacent Co­(II) ions to produce an infinite 2D floor-like framework. Compared with 3, the 4,4′-bipy ligands in 2 coordinate to one Co­(II) ion, which results in a mononuclear structure, while the 2D framework is formed by Hppc– anions. The metal–ligand ratio, as is well-known, can markedly affect complex architectures, which is also well proven by our result. The Co­(II) ion in 3 is simplified to a three-connecting node. Therefore, the entire 2D network of 3 may be classified as a 3-connected net having a point symbol of (63), as calculated by TOPOS. The Co···Co distances are 9.760 (Hppc– bridge) and 11.343 Å (4,4′-bipy bridge), which means the weaker magnetic superexchange interactions being between adjacent Co···Co. Some C–H···O interactions exist between adjacent 2D layers. In these cases, the O atoms originate from Hppc– ions and the H atoms come from benzimidazole rings. The H···O distances (bond angles) in 3 are 2.41 Å (127.7°) for C18–H18···O4, 2.58 Å (118.6°) for C17–H17···O4, 2.62 Å (136.6°) for C23–H23···O4, and 2.60 Å (169.8°) for C17–H17···O3. The lengths of C–H···O hydrogen bonds agree well with those reported in the literature. Then the neighboring 2D layers with interplanar separations of 3.823 Å (centroid–centroid separations: 4.010 Å) are associated together through π···π stacking interactions between the pyridine rings of Hppc– ligands resulting in a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: Polymer 4 has a 1D double ladder-like chain structure. The Co­(II) ion in 4 is five-coordinated and within a distorted trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) environment with O1, N3, N4A atoms from two ppc2– ligands in which the carboxylate O atoms adopted a μ1-η1:η0 coordination mode. The remaining N2, N7B atoms come from two pbbbm ligands (a). The distorted trigonal bipyramidal shape can be reflected in the index of trigonality (τCo1 = 0.76). The bond angles surrounding the Co­(II) ion vary from 77.26(11) to 174.66(10)°. The Co–N lengths range from 2.018(3) to 2.066(3) Å. The Co–O length is 2.204(2) Å. The double N–N bridge from two ppc2– ligands produces an approximate centrosymmetric quasiplanar Co­(N–N)2Co hexagon with Co1···Co1A = 3.903 Å (a). This means there are magnetic superexchange interactions between adjacent Co···Co. The bond angles of Co1–N3–N4 and Co1A–N4–N3 are 136.3(2) and 120.7(2), respectively. The bond lengths of Co1–N3 and Co1–N4 are 2.018(3) and 2.065(3), respectively. This results in the Co1 and Co1A atoms being asymmetric. The adjuvant pbbbm ligands link the Co­(II) ions (the adjacent Co···Co distances are 12.528 Å) to form a limitless 1D double chain, which is shown in b. It appears that there is no direct hydrogen bonding in the double chain; however, the intramolecular edge-to-face CH/π interaction was 2.608 Å (H/π-plane separation: 2.520 Å; dihedral angle: 100.04°) between the intermolecular benzimidazole rings. During the forming of the double chain, such π···π interactions play a vital role. In 2D layered supramolecular stacking of 4, two types of π···π stacking interactions are seen. One type of π···π interaction comes from intermolecular benzimidazole rings (interplanar separations: 3.335 Å; centroid–centroid separations: 4.190 Å). The other is CH/π interaction 2.720 Å (dihedral angle: 79.4°; H/π-plane separation: 2.651 Å). And it is shorter than the average distance (ca. 2.86 Å) of the sp2-CH···π. The foregoing two types of stacking interactions extend the 1D chains to 2D layers. The 2D layers are further bridged through the weaker C–H···N hydrogen bonds for 4 [H/N distances (bond angles): 2.765 Å (153.95°) for C11–H11···N5; 2.613 Å (137.79°) for C40–H40···N5]. They are in the normal range of C–H···N hydrogen bonds. This results in a 3D supramolecular structure.

The other is CH/π interaction 2.720 Å (dihedral angle: 79.4°; H/π-plane separation: 2.651 Å). And it is shorter than the average distance (ca. 2.86 Å) of the sp2-CH⋅⋅⋅π. The foregoing two types of stacking interactions extend the 1D chains to 2D layers. The 2D layers are further bridged through the weaker C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds for 4 [H/N distances (bond angles): 2.765 Å (153.95°) for C11-H11⋅⋅⋅N5; 2.613 Å (137.79°) for C40-H40⋅⋅⋅N5]. They are in the normal range of C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds. This results in a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: X-ray determination revealed that complex 5 is a binuclear molecule that comprised two Co­(II) cations, two mbbbm units, and four ppc2– ligands (a). 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Each Co­(II) ion in 5 is six-coordinated and within a distorted octahedral environment with O2, O3, N3, N8 atoms from two Hppc– units, and N1, N4 atoms from two mbbbm ligands. The bond angles around a Co­(II) ion vary from 77.00(11) to 170.96(12) Å. The Co–N lengths fall in the range of 2.127(3)–2.156(3), and the Co–O lengths are 2.105(3) and 2.106(3) Å. In 5, two mbbbm ligands adopting stable cis-conformation link two Co­(II) ions to form the binuclear molecule. The four Hppc– ligands bind to two different Co­(II) centers, and the intermetallic distance of Co1···Co1A is 13.622 Å. This means there are weaker magnetic superexchange interactions between adjacent Co···Co. There are many aromatic rings in 5 that may form a variety of π···π stacking interactions, which give rise to a 2D infinite packing structure (b). The 2D layers are further outspread to 3D structures by the intermolecular C–H···N hydrogen bonds [H/N distances (bond angles): 2.589 Å (153.24°) for C39–H39···N7 and 2.734 Å (143.06°) for C1–H1···N7]. Additionally, intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds are seen [H/O distances (bond angles): 2.687 Å (158.53°) for C27–H27···O3; 2.701 Å (144.90°) for C27–H27···O4], which further stabilize the 3D supramolecular structures.

Each Co(II) ion in 5 is six-coordinated and within a distorted octahedral environment with O2, O3, N3, N8 atoms from two Hppc- units, and N1, N4 atoms from two mbbbm ligands. In 5, two mbbbm ligands adopting stable cis-conformation link two Co(II) ions to form the binuclear molecule. The four Hppc- ligands bind to two different Co(II) centers, and the intermetallic distance of Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1A is 13.622 Å. This means there are weaker magnetic superexchange interactions between adjacent Co⋅⋅⋅Co. The 2D layers are further outspread to 3D structures by the intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds [H/N distances (bond angles): 2.589 Å (153.24°) for C39-H39⋅⋅⋅N7 and 2.734 Å (143.06°) for C1-H1⋅⋅⋅N7]. elements.content: Five multidimensional Co­(II)-complexes (from 0D to 3D) offer fantastic ways to investigate the effective magnetic interactions between the Co­(II) ions through H2ppc or N-heterocyclic auxiliary bridge, although they are organized into strikingly dissimilar supramolecular structures. Solid state magnetic susceptibility measurements on a crystalline sample in the temperature range of 2–300 K at a field of 1 kOe were utilized to study the magnetic properties of 1–5. The bulk purity of 1–5 was substantiated through comparing the PXRD of experimental result to a simulated one of single crystal structure (Figure S1). The magnetic susceptibilities of 1–5 relating to temperature dependence, expressed in the form of χM and χM T versus T are present in , , , , and . To investigate the Co2 unit, the molecular weight for the magnetic data of 4 were calculated and its value is 1200.98, and χM was the molar magnetic susceptibility per Co2 unit for 4. The χM T data of 1–5 at 300 and 2 K are listed in . The χM T data for 1–5 at 300 K are greater than those expected for one (1.875 cm3·K·mol–1; S = 3/2 with g = 2), two (3.75 cm3·K·mol–1; S = 3/2 with g = 2) or three (5.625 cm3·K·mol–1; S = 3/2 with g = 2) magnetically isolated Co­(II) ions, respectively, due to the presence of spin–orbital coupling interactions. For 1, as the sample was cooled, the χM T data decreased gradually from 300 to 23 K, and then the χM T data decreased abruptly to 8 K, due to spin–orbital coupling and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions. Under 8 K, the χM T data abruptly increased to a maximum of 5.55 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, which can be attributed to some minor impurities. Actually, we can see from the magnetic susceptibility curve that there are some minor impurities in 1. Through the repeated synthesis and testing, similar results were obtained. For 2–5, all the χM T values drop gradually as the temperature decreased. For 1–5, the main factor associated with the decrease of all the χM T values is spin–orbital coupling, and the secondary factor is the antiferromagnetic interactions between neighboring Co­(II) ions. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (χM –1) in the range of 25–300 K (1), 50–300 K (2), 2–300 K (3), 35–300 K (4), or 50–300 K (5) adheres to the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ) (Figure S2). The obtained Curie and Weiss constants were listed in . The expected C values of octahedral high-spin Co­(II) ions range from 2.75 to 3.4 cm3·K·mol–1. The obtained C values of 1 and 3 were just in the anticipated range. The C value of 4 is slightly lower than 2.75 cm3·K·mol–1, while the C values of 2 and 5 are bigger than 3.4 cm3·K·mol–1. This demonstrates that there is a larger contribution of Co­(II) orbital in an octahedral ligand field or there are some minor impurities. It is well-known that spin–orbit coupling, which can give rise to a decrease of χM T with a temperature decrease and a negative θ value, is notable for the 4T1g state of Co­(II) ions in an octahedral environment. The negative values of θ for 1–5 indicate the presence of spin–orbital coupling of Co­(II) or antiferromagnetic interactions in 1–5.

Magnetic Properties of 1-5 

Five multidimensional Co(II)-complexes (from 0D to 3D) offer fantastic ways to investigate the effective magnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions through H2ppc or N-heterocyclic auxiliary bridge, although they are organized into strikingly dissimilar supramolecular structures. Solid state magnetic susceptibility measurements on a crystalline sample in the temperature range of 2-300 K at a field of 1 kOe were utilized to study the magnetic properties of 1-5. The bulk purity of 1-5 was substantiated through comparing the PXRD of experimental result to a simulated one of single crystal structure (Figure S1). The magnetic susceptibilities of 1-5 relating to temperature dependence, expressed in the form of χM and χM T versus T are present in , , , , and . To investigate the Co2 unit, the molecular weight for the magnetic data of 4 were calculated and its value is 1200.98, and χM was the molar magnetic susceptibility per Co2 unit for 4. The χM T data of 1-5 at 300 and 2 K are listed in . The χM T data for 1-5 at 300 K are greater than those expected for one (1.875 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1; S = 3/2 with g = 2), two (3.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1; S = 3/2 with g = 2) or three (5.625 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1; S = 3/2 with g = 2) magnetically isolated Co(II) ions, respectively, due to the presence of spin-orbital coupling interactions. For 1, as the sample was cooled, the χM T data decreased gradually from 300 to 23 K, and then the χM T data decreased abruptly to 8 K, due to spin-orbital coupling and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions. Under 8 K, the χM T data abruptly increased to a maximum of 5.55 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which can be attributed to some minor impurities. Actually, we can see from the magnetic susceptibility curve that there are some minor impurities in 1. Through the repeated synthesis and testing, similar results were obtained. For 2-5, all the χM T values drop gradually as the temperature decreased. For 1-5, the main factor associated with the decrease of all the χM T values is spin-orbital coupling, and the secondary factor is the antiferromagnetic interactions between neighboring Co(II) ions. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (χM -1) in the range of 25-300 K (1), 50-300 K (2), 2-300 K (3), 35-300 K (4), or 50-300 K (5) adheres to the Curie-Weiss law, χM = C/(T - θ) (Figure S2). The obtained Curie and Weiss constants were listed in . The expected C values of octahedral high-spin Co(II) ions range from 2.75 to 3.4 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. The obtained C values of 1 and 3 were just in the anticipated range. The C value of 4 is slightly lower than 2.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, while the C values of 2 and 5 are bigger than 3.4 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. This demonstrates that there is a larger contribution of Co(II) orbital in an octahedral ligand field or there are some minor impurities. It is well-known that spin-orbit coupling, which can give rise to a decrease of χM T with a temperature decrease and a negative θ value, is notable for the 4T1g state of Co(II) ions in an octahedral environment. The negative values of θ for 1-5 indicate the presence of spin-orbital coupling of Co(II) or antiferromagnetic interactions in 1-5.

elements.content: Since the distances of two Co­(II) connected with the Hppc– ligands in 1 are all longer (5.528, 5.930, 6.011, and 7.854 Å) than the intradimer Co1···Co2 distances (3.815 Å) (named as Co2 units; a), the interdimer interactions can be roughly considered as the influence of the molecular field. In our study, the long Hppc– ligands only provided weak interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. Similarly in 4, because the distances of two Co­(II) that were jointed through the pbbbm are longer (12.528 Å) than the intradimer Co1···Co1A separations (3.903 Å; ). Thus, the interdimer interactions can also be considered as the influence of molecular field. The total antiferromagnetic exchange should therefore be mainly caused by the double N–N bridge binuclear Co­(N–N)2Co for both 1 and 4 (a and a). It should be noted that the end-on oxygen-bridged complexes and end-on azide-bridged complexes with the carboxylate ligands are widely studied in this magnetic system. However, the double N–N bridge Co­(N–N)2Co constructions in 1 and 4 are rarely observed. Figure S4 shows the isothermal magnetization with a field from −80 to 80 kOe at 2.0 K. Following with the field above 70 kOe, the magnetization of 4 increases little by little, and the value of 2.72 Nβ at 80 kOe is far from being saturated. These features are in line with the antiferromagnetic properties in the Co2 units.

In our study, the long Hppc- ligands only provided weak interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. Similarly in 4, because the distances of two Co(II) that were jointed through the pbbbm are longer (12.528 Å) than the intradimer Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1A separations (3.903 Å; ). Thus, the interdimer interactions can also be considered as the influence of molecular field. The total antiferromagnetic exchange should therefore be mainly caused by the double N-N bridge binuclear Co(N-N)2Co for both 1 and 4 (a and a). It should be noted that the end-on oxygen-bridged complexes and end-on azide-bridged complexes with the carboxylate ligands are widely studied in this magnetic system. However, the double N-N bridge Co(N-N)2Co constructions in 1 and 4 are rarely observed. Figure S4 shows the isothermal magnetization with a field from -80 to 80 kOe at 2.0 K. Following with the field above 70 kOe, the magnetization of 4 increases little by little, and the value of 2.72 Nβ at 80 kOe is far from being saturated. These features are in line with the antiferromagnetic properties in the Co2 units.

elements.content: The distances among Co­(II) centers for 2, 3, and 5 were bridged by the long Hppc–, 4,4′-bipy, or mbbbm spacer ligands, which should eliminate an efficient direct exchange between Co­(II) ions. At 2 K, Figure S4 showed the M vs. H plots of 2, 3, and 5. The M(H) curves gradually increase to a value of 7.34 Nβ per Co3 unit (2.45 Nβ per Co unit) for 2, 2.70 Nβ per Co unit for 3, and 5.08 Nβ per Co2 unit (2.54 Nβ per Co unit) for 5 at 80 kOe. For octahedral Co­(II) ions at low-temperature, an S = 1/2 ground state can be commonly seen due to the total effect of spin–orbit coupling and crystal field. And there exists the expected magnetization value of 2.1–2.5 Nβ with g = 4.1–5.0. At high fields, the observed magnetization values of ∼2.5 Nβ for 2, 3, and 5 are in line with the value anticipated for single uncompensated S = 1/2 spin.

For octahedral Co(II) ions at low-temperature, an S = 1/2 ground state can be commonly seen due to the total effect of spin-orbit coupling and crystal field. And there exists the expected magnetization value of 2.1-2.5 Nβ with g = 4.1-5.0. elements.content: In summary, utilizing a asymmetric, conjugated H2ppc in the presence or absence of auxiliary ligands, five cobalt­(II) complexes were synthesized successfully. Polymer 1 is a 3D network with the Schläfli symbol (42·62·82)2­(42·6·83)2. Polymer 2 includes a mononuclear subunit and an infinite 2D framework subunit, while polymer 3 is 2D sheet structure. Polymer 4 is a one-dimensional double ladder-like chain structure. Complex 5 possesses a binuclear structure. Magnetization data for 1 with the Co2 units show the antiferromagnetic coupling in the Co2 units. There are some minor impurities in 1. No signal was observed in the out-of-phase (χ′′) plots of 1, and the hysteresis loop was not detected in 1 upon cycling of the field, which proves no long-range magnetic ordering. For 4 with similar Co2 units, it also exhibits antiferromagnetic coupling. Additionally, following with the field above 70 kOe, the magnetization increases slowly, and the value of 2.72 Nβ at 80 kOe is far from saturation, which is in line with the antiferromagnetic nature in the Co2 units. Similarly, 2, 3, and 5 display weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The observed magnetization values, which were ∼2.5 Nβ at high field for 2, 3, and 5, are in accordance with the value anticipated for single uncompensated S = 1/2 spin. Our results exhibit the value of crystal engineering of metal–organic complexes in the area of molecular based magnetic materials and will inspire further study in this research field.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, utilizing a asymmetric, conjugated H2ppc in the presence or absence of auxiliary ligands, five cobalt(II) complexes were synthesized successfully. Polymer 1 is a 3D network with the Schläfli symbol (42⋅62⋅82)2(42⋅6⋅83)2. Polymer 2 includes a mononuclear subunit and an infinite 2D framework subunit, while polymer 3 is 2D sheet structure. Polymer 4 is a one-dimensional double ladder-like chain structure. Complex 5 possesses a binuclear structure. Magnetization data for 1 with the Co2 units show the antiferromagnetic coupling in the Co2 units. There are some minor impurities in 1. No signal was observed in the out-of-phase (χ'') plots of 1, and the hysteresis loop was not detected in 1 upon cycling of the field, which proves no long-range magnetic ordering. For 4 with similar Co2 units, it also exhibits antiferromagnetic coupling. Additionally, following with the field above 70 kOe, the magnetization increases slowly, and the value of 2.72 Nβ at 80 kOe is far from saturation, which is in line with the antiferromagnetic nature in the Co2 units. Similarly, 2, 3, and 5 display weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The observed magnetization values, which were ~2.5 Nβ at high field for 2, 3, and 5, are in accordance with the value anticipated for single uncompensated S = 1/2 spin. Our results exhibit the value of crystal engineering of metal-organic complexes in the area of molecular based magnetic materials and will inspire further study in this research field.

 5 was prepared similar to that of 2 except that mbbbm was replaced by 4,4'-bipy. 5 was a pink block crystal, which was gathered. Yield: 67%. Elemental anal.
